segment.source: Set up the game project
segment.target: Set up the game project

segment.source: The first step in assembling your game is to set up a project in Microsoft Visual Studio in such a way that you minimize the amount of code infrastructure work you need to do.
segment.target: The first step in assembling your game is to set up a project in Microsoft Visual Studio in such a way that you minimize the amount of code infrastructure work you need to do.

segment.source: Set up the game project
segment.target: Set up the game project

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: The first step in assembling your game is to set up a project in Microsoft Visual Studio in such a way that you minimize the amount of code infrastructure work you need to do.
segment.target: The first step in assembling your game is to set up a project in Microsoft Visual Studio in such a way that you minimize the amount of code infrastructure work you need to do.

segment.source: You can save yourself a lot of time and hassle by using the right template and configuring the project specifically for game development.
segment.target: You can save yourself a lot of time and hassle by using the right template and configuring the project specifically for game development.

segment.source: We step you through the setup and configuration of a simple game project.
segment.target: We step you through the setup and configuration of a simple game project.

segment.source: Objective
segment.target: Objective

segment.source: To learn how to set up a Direct3D game project in Visual Studio.
segment.target: To learn how to set up a Direct3D game project in Visual Studio.

segment.source: Setting up the game project
segment.target: Setting up the game project

segment.source: You can write a game from scratch, with just a handy text editor, a few samples, and a hat full of raw brainpower.
segment.target: You can write a game from scratch, with just a handy text editor, a few samples, and a hat full of raw brainpower.

segment.source: But that probably isn't the most effective use of your time.
segment.target: But that probably isn't the most effective use of your time.

segment.source: If you're new to Universal Windows Platform (UWP) development, why not let Visual Studio shoulder some of the burden?
segment.target: If you're new to Universal Windows Platform (UWP) development, why not let Visual Studio shoulder some of the burden?

segment.source: Here's what to do to get your project off to a roaring start.
segment.target: Here's what to do to get your project off to a roaring start.

segment.source: 1. Pick the right template
segment.target: 1. Pick the right template

segment.source: A Visual Studio template is a collection of settings and code files that target a specific type of app based on the preferred language and technology.
segment.target: A Visual Studio template is a collection of settings and code files that target a specific type of app based on the preferred language and technology.

segment.source: In Microsoft Visual Studio 2015, you'll find a number of templates that can dramatically ease game and graphics app development.
segment.target: In Microsoft Visual Studio 2015, you'll find a number of templates that can dramatically ease game and graphics app development.

segment.source: If you don't use a template, you must develop much of the basic graphics rendering and display framework yourself, which can be a bit of a chore to a new game developer.
segment.target: If you don't use a template, you must develop much of the basic graphics rendering and display framework yourself, which can be a bit of a chore to a new game developer.

segment.source: The right template for this tutorial, is the one titled DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows).
segment.target: The right template for this tutorial, is the one titled DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows).

segment.source: In Visual Studio 2015, click File... New Project, and then:
segment.target: In Visual Studio 2015, click File... New Project, and then:

segment.source: From Templates, select Visual C++, Windows, Universal.
segment.target: From Templates, select Visual C++, Windows, Universal.

segment.source: In the center pane, select DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows).
segment.target: In the center pane, select DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows).

segment.source: Give your game project a name, and click OK.
segment.target: Give your game project a name, and click OK.

segment.source: selecting the direct3d application template
segment.target: selecting the direct3d application template

segment.source: This template provides you with the basic framework for a UWP app using DirectX with C++.
segment.target: This template provides you with the basic framework for a UWP app using DirectX with C++.

segment.source: Go on, build and run it with F5!
segment.target: Go on, build and run it with F5!

segment.source: Check out that powder blue screen.
segment.target: Check out that powder blue screen.

segment.source: Take a moment and review the code that the template provides.
segment.target: Take a moment and review the code that the template provides.

segment.source: Tthe template creates multiple code files containing the basic functionality for a UWP app using DirectX with C++.
segment.target: Tthe template creates multiple code files containing the basic functionality for a UWP app using DirectX with C++.

segment.source: We talk more about the other code files in step 3.
segment.target: We talk more about the other code files in step 3.

segment.source: Right now, let's quickly inspect App.h.
segment.target: Right now, let's quickly inspect App.h.

segment.source: You create these 5 methods, Initialize, SetWindow, Load, Run, and Uninitialize, when implementing the IFrameworkView interface that defines a view provider.
segment.target: You create these 5 methods, Initialize, SetWindow, Load, Run, and Uninitialize, when implementing the IFrameworkView interface that defines a view provider.

segment.source: These methods are run by the app singleton that is created when your game is launched, and load all your app's resources as well as connect the appropriate event handlers.
segment.target: These methods are run by the app singleton that is created when your game is launched, and load all your app's resources as well as connect the appropriate event handlers.

segment.source: Your main method is in the App.cpp source file.
segment.target: Your main method is in the App.cpp source file.

segment.source: It looks like this:
segment.target: It looks like this:

segment.source: Right now, it creates an instance of the Direct3D view provider from the view provider factory (Direct3DApplicationSource, defined in App.h), and passes it to the app singleton to run (CoreApplication::Run).
segment.target: Right now, it creates an instance of the Direct3D view provider from the view provider factory (Direct3DApplicationSource, defined in App.h), and passes it to the app singleton to run (CoreApplication::Run).

segment.source: This means that the starting point for your game lives in the body of the implementation of the IFrameworkView::Run method, in this case, App::Run.
segment.target: This means that the starting point for your game lives in the body of the implementation of the IFrameworkView::Run method, in this case, App::Run.

segment.source: Here's the code:
segment.target: Here's the code:

segment.source: If the window for your game isn't closed, this dispatches all events, updates the timer, and renders and presents the results of your graphics pipeline.
segment.target: If the window for your game isn't closed, this dispatches all events, updates the timer, and renders and presents the results of your graphics pipeline.

segment.source: We talk about this in greater detail in Defining the game's UWP framework and Assembling the rendering pipeline.
segment.target: We talk about this in greater detail in Defining the game's UWP framework and Assembling the rendering pipeline.

segment.source: At this point, you should have a sense of the basic code structure of a UWP DirectX game.
segment.target: At this point, you should have a sense of the basic code structure of a UWP DirectX game.

segment.source: 2. Review and update the package.appxmanifest file
segment.target: 2. Review and update the package.appxmanifest file

segment.source: The code files aren't all there is to the template.
segment.target: The code files aren't all there is to the template.

segment.source: The package.appxmanifest file contains metadata about your project that are used for packaging and launching your game and for submission to the Windows Store.
segment.target: The package.appxmanifest file contains metadata about your project that are used for packaging and launching your game and for submission to the Windows Store.

segment.source: It also contains important info the player's system uses to provide access to the system resources the game needs to run.
segment.target: It also contains important info the player's system uses to provide access to the system resources the game needs to run.

segment.source: Launch the Manifest Designer by double-clicking the package.appxmanifest file in Solution Explorer.
segment.target: Launch the Manifest Designer by double-clicking the package.appxmanifest file in Solution Explorer.

segment.source: You see this view:
segment.target: You see this view:

segment.source: the package.appx manifest editor.
segment.target: the package.appx manifest editor.

segment.source: For more info about the package.appxmanifest file and packaging, see Manifest Designer.
segment.target: For more info about the package.appxmanifest file and packaging, see Manifest Designer.

segment.source: For now, take a look at the Capabilities tab and look at the options provided.
segment.target: For now, take a look at the Capabilities tab and look at the options provided.

segment.source: the default capabilities of a direct3d app.
segment.target: the default capabilities of a direct3d app.

segment.source: If you don't select the capabilities that your game uses, such as access to the Internet for global high score board, you won't be able to access the corresponding resources or features.
segment.target: If you don't select the capabilities that your game uses, such as access to the Internet for global high score board, you won't be able to access the corresponding resources or features.

segment.source: When you create a new game, make sure that you select the capabilities that your game needs to run!
segment.target: When you create a new game, make sure that you select the capabilities that your game needs to run!

segment.source: Now, let's look at the rest of the files that come with the DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template.
segment.target: Now, let's look at the rest of the files that come with the DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template.

segment.source: 3. Review the included libraries and headers
segment.target: 3. Review the included libraries and headers

segment.source: There are a few files we haven't looked at yet.
segment.target: There are a few files we haven't looked at yet.

segment.source: These files provide additional tools and support common to Direct3D game development scenarios.
segment.target: These files provide additional tools and support common to Direct3D game development scenarios.

segment.source: Template Source File
segment.target: Template Source File

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: StepTimer.h
segment.target: StepTimer.h

segment.source: Defines a high-resolution timer useful for gaming or interactive rendering apps.
segment.target: Defines a high-resolution timer useful for gaming or interactive rendering apps.

segment.source: Sample3DSceneRenderer.h/.cpp
segment.target: Sample3DSceneRenderer.h/.cpp

segment.source: Defines a basic renderer implementation that connects a Direct3D swap chain and graphics adapter to your UWP using DirectX.
segment.target: Defines a basic renderer implementation that connects a Direct3D swap chain and graphics adapter to your UWP using DirectX.

segment.source: DirectXHelper.h
segment.target: DirectXHelper.h

segment.source: Implements a single method, DX::ThrowIfFailed, that converts the error HRESULT values returned by DirectX APIs into Windows Runtime exceptions.
segment.target: Implements a single method, DX::ThrowIfFailed, that converts the error HRESULT values returned by DirectX APIs into Windows Runtime exceptions.

segment.source: Use this method to put a break point for debugging DirectX errors.
segment.target: Use this method to put a break point for debugging DirectX errors.

segment.source: pch.h/.cpp
segment.target: pch.h/.cpp

segment.source: Contains all the Windows system includes for the APIs used by a Direct3D app, including the DirectX 11 APIs.
segment.target: Contains all the Windows system includes for the APIs used by a Direct3D app, including the DirectX 11 APIs.

segment.source: SamplePixelShader.hlsl
segment.target: SamplePixelShader.hlsl

segment.source: Contains the high-level shader language (HLSL) code for a very basic pixel shader.
segment.target: Contains the high-level shader language (HLSL) code for a very basic pixel shader.

segment.source: SampleVertexShader.hlsl
segment.target: SampleVertexShader.hlsl

segment.source: Contains the high-level shader language (HLSL) code for a very basic vertex shader.
segment.target: Contains the high-level shader language (HLSL) code for a very basic vertex shader.

segment.source: Next steps
segment.target: Next steps

segment.source: At this point, you can create a UWP with DirectX game project and identify the components and files provided by the DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template.
segment.target: At this point, you can create a UWP with DirectX game project and identify the components and files provided by the DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template.

segment.source: In the next tutorial, Defining the game's UWP framework, we work with a completed game and examine how it uses and extends many of the concepts and components that the template provides.
segment.target: In the next tutorial, Defining the game's UWP framework, we work with a completed game and examine how it uses and extends many of the concepts and components that the template provides.
